messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] honesty  (was homesty - was discipline)  OT
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 7/7/2000 6:02:46 AM US Mountain Standard Time, FUNLists@IQCweb.com writes:
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 7/7/2000 6:02:46 AM US Mountain Standard Time,
FUNLists@... writes:

<< did anyone else keep opening these messages
thinking that they would contain discussions about really messy houses? >>

Very funny Billy... I did keep looking at it and wonder if it was suppose to
be honesty or some new unschooling word that I wasn't familiar with.

Dawn F

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] honesty  (was homesty - was discipline)  OT
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 7/7/00 8:02:37 AM Central Daylight Time, FUNLists@IQCweb.com writes:
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 7/7/00 8:02:37 AM Central Daylight Time,
FUNLists@... writes:

<< Is it just my warped mind, or did anyone else keep opening these messages
thinking that they would contain discussions about really messy houses? I
thought homesty was a clever word. Obviously derived from pigsty and perhaps
peoplesty would be technically more accurate, but homesty just had a good
sound to it. Oh well.

>>
Hee heehee! :) How funny! Thanks for the chuckle! ~Karen

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] honesty  (was homesty - was discipline)  OT
messages.msgSnippet: actually, i thought your post was quite amusing. that  typo was bugging me too, but i was just too lazy to fix it. amy ... From: Billy or Nancy
messages.messageBody:
actually, i thought your post was quite amusing. that typo was bugging me
too, but i was just too lazy to fix it.
amy
----- Original Message -----
From: Billy or Nancy <FUNLists@...>
To: <Unschooling-dotcom@egroups.com>
Sent: Friday, July 07, 2000 6:01 AM
Subject: [Unschooling-dotcom] honesty (was homesty - was discipline) OT


> Okay, normally I can ignore typos but I had to change the subject line on
> this one.
>
> Is it just my warped mind, or did anyone else keep opening these messages
> thinking that they would contain discussions about really messy houses? I
> thought homesty was a clever word. Obviously derived from pigsty and
perhaps
> peoplesty would be technically more accurate, but homesty just had a good
> sound to it. Oh well.
>
> Sorry if I mislead you into reading this message and thinking I had
> something to contribute about honesty.
>
> Billy
